title: How to ask great questions on Quora - Quora

response.answer_text: As a Quora reviewer, I have seen many, many questions that were undoubtedly badly written. They are characterized by rambling, misspellings and grammatical errors, bizarre assumptions and over-specificity. The worst leave the reader wondering what on earth is being asked. Some of them have long unformatted details that go on for screens, effectively answering the question right in the question details. A great question on Quora is a sort of koan that elicits thoughtful answers. These are the Needs Attention categories available to reviewers: Needs More InformationNeeds to Be ClearerNeeds Spelling, Grammar, or Formatting EditsNeeds to Be Phrased as a QuestionNeeds to Be a Complete SentenceContains Multiple QuestionsNeeds to Be ShorterToo Reliant on Question DetailsRhetorical QuestionNeeds to Be Phrased More NeutrallyAdvertisement or Self-Promotional QuestionPossible SpamNeeds to Be Written in EnglishPoll QuestionToo Many TopicsNeeds Topic AdjustmentDirect QuestionObsolete QuestionAnswered in Question DetailsContains Unnecessary ProfanitySpecific Legal QuestionSpecific Medical QuestionWriting an adequate question on Quora is not too hard. One of the easier methods is to copy the phrasing of a popular question. (In fact, it's nice to have some sorts of questions in a standard format, rather than a hodgepodge of different wordings that make it hard for others to find your question.) Writing a really good question is harder. I recommend taking the time to read the questions that have already been written on the main topic. You may find that there's already one that answers your question, or one that asks your question but isn't worded well. If you're confident in your ability to write good questions, you might consider editing the poorly written one. (This will mean that you will not get credits for followers to this question. However, Reviewers are tasked to Redirect Questions that are substantially similar, so you might find yours merged into an older question, anyway.) Things which I am aiming for when I edit a question on Quora:  the wording: One clear sentence. As an example, the original question was "I live in an authoritarian regime. How do I effectively communicate with others without getting into trouble?" I changed this to: How do I effectively communicate with others without getting into trouble when I live in an authoritarian regime?I don't think it's necessary to put the premise in the question itself. Self-referentially, this question has a simple expression, "What characterizes a well-written question on Quora?" and a further clarification that this is concerning the writing within the details. (It could have been written, "What does a good question on Quora look like, aside from interesting topics", which would have been far more confusing.)Not written in Jeopardy!-eseThe question should read naturally, rather than being a statement that has been forced into a query.Clear and interesting question details, as necessary.Not every question needs details, but if it does, they should draw the potential answerer in and make the case for why this is a compelling question by giving context or adding the thoughts of the questioner. Be careful with these as it can easily lead to adding in other questions and over-broadening the scope of the question.Designed to elicit interesting answers.Questions that draw out personal experience work well on Quora.Good questions inspire expert analysis or a well-curated synopsis of information that helps distinguish a great answer on Quora from the masses of facts available elsewhere on the 'net.Seek sincerely.This one is subtle, and I do not have a succinct example of what I mean. Quora's power users are often flooded with demands for answers, and frequent answerers in a topic often get to a point of burnout from the repetitious and uninformed nature of the questions asked. (e.g. When it comes to the topic of "Germany", why are Quora users so obsessed with questions about Hitler, Jews and WWII?) A little homework by the questioner can make the difference between a cliché and a subtle detail that brings out an impassioned outpouring of explanation.Simplicity is good.Questions that are applicable to more than one particular situation generally work better. The exception to this might be in the Dating and Relationships topic, where specific details lead to answers tailored to the situation at hand.the context: Set the primary topic accurately.Food is a vague topic. Usually you can find something a little more specific.Choose additional topics with care.Questions about Europe really don't need every single country listed in the details. You want to attract the attention of people who actually care about your question. You'll pick up followers and answerers from related questions while someone is browsing through Quora.Check again to see that your question is written clearly. Avoid abbreviations except where commonly used within that context (writing HIV is appropriate, rather than Human Immunodeficiency Virus, writing "froyo" is somewhat obnoxious). Check against the list of Needs Attention tags. Consider whether your question benefits Quora as a community in addition to your own personal curiosity. If you can reword the question to have broader appeal, you should probably do so. (But avoid making it so broad that it is unanswerable!) If you're having trouble wording your question well, Need help wording a Quora question? is open to assisting you. Additional resources: Kent Palmer's answer to Is it a good idea to tell people on Quora, "Your question is stupid"?What makes for a popular Quora question?What is the appropriate use for the various Needs Improvement and limited distribution topic tags?

Ive got a question which i fear if raised it “as” a question on Quora, It would never see the light of day, so I’m “answering” here w hopes someone will help me understand how to “work” this issue I have - namely, how to get questions posted in what is a clearly a subjective environment of applying a posting criteria to these questions. Below is the gist of my issue and my frustration in getting QUESTIONS posed on Quora. ANSWERS, i have no problems with. They get easily posted. And I’ve submitted many, a number of which have gotten a good response. So, on to my issue: Since I’ve been on Quora I’ve had a few “questions” get not allowed. But no specifics, just a bunch of pre-written bullets sent to me as to what “may” be the reason. I believe I have a decent command of the English language so I SMH about that. None of these questions were socially controversial or off color. More frustrating: I notice a LOT of OTHER questions from others on Quora, that are very lengthy and sometimes are “statements” more than questions. And THEY have “gotten through” (posted)!! So I’m wondering: are there some underlying “ “clubs” of reviewers on Quora who allow some to post but not others, based on some hidden and subjective (certainly not objective), criteria?? A recent disconcerting example: I had a “question,” an innocuous one, about sports - no foul language and basically, what I thought was, good grammar. I tried and tried but kept getting pushback - a pre-written page sent to me as to what may be “wrong” w my question. But my question could never get posted, even when I edited it 4 it 5 times to rephrase it but still KEEP TO my damn question. Then, out of the blue, my question got edited by whomever in the “Question Posing Police” and It POSTED (which I soon took down … hey, it’s MY question!!)!!! No one contacted me or ASKED me if THEIR “interpretation” of MY OWN question was ok. Whaaat?? Seems a very “White House” kind of jazz is going on, like what they do w the CDC. But at least w them we KNOW their criteria, a priori. Maybe there’s an explanation of how the question posing “works” here?? I’d like to know what are the Quora “rules” on all this?? I really like the concept of Quora, enjoy it’s breath & depth, and have posted a ton of answers. But “questions” seem to be a real problem. There seems to be an apparent uneven criteria being used in “evaluating“ the questions being submitted. A weird form on censorship?? Can someone enlighten me??

One simple way to ask great question is to ask an honest question for which you are seeking an answer. Some points to remember while writing the question: Has the question been already answered? This you can find when you draft your question and Quora suggests with possible similar questions. If you find a question similar to yours, you can go to the answers of that question. If you are not satisfied with any of the answers, you can write a new question emphasizing on what is lacking.From similar questions you will come to know people who have answered that question and who has understanding or expertise on the subject of your question. This information is very useful because with that you can direct your question to the person who had already answered similar question and there are more chances of your question receiving more answers.Give relevant background and precise information which would help someone understand what you are looking for and answer to the best of their abilities. Pictures and links help sometimes.Adhere to Quota's Be Nice Be Respectful and sensitive to your audience in your questions, and you will put a great question.Be genuine and avoid trolling questions and you will add much value to the platform through your questions.

Look, this is certainly not the way. Being ‘amazingly good’ at asking questions has absolutely no value in Quora. It can only help yourself with the questions you have. But there are already a multitude of ways to get your questions answered: GoogleBooks (visit a library)Other people around youI would say the best questions for Quora are the ones where this method just won’t work, so you need more outside people: when the topic is obscurewhen it’s very personal for you, and you look for someone in the same situationwhen you really need an expert to answerwhen you are interested in a wide perspective from lots of people (hope the question gets some traction there)One more thing: Quora is not Facebook, and upvotes are stupid. This is not high school. A “Top Writer” is not more knowledgeable than all others, it’s just someone whose answers people enjoy reading. That doesn’t make them true. A lot of writers get sucked into an upvote game, where the answer deteriorates because it starts following a certain style, or strategy. Even worse, a lot of ‘answers’ don’t actually answer the question, and instead sit there to evoke emotion in the reader, in order to provide serotonin to the reader’s brain, like a cheap drug dealer on a street corner, using unnecessarily heavy metaphors. Just ask any question that pops into your head.

Life is full of questions. Questions, for some of which we are able to find answers, and for some we are simply unable to. You want to know when is the next flight to Paris. But you are asking at airport’s help desk about all the flights going to France. In such a case, you cannot expect to get the correct answer. Can you? Maybe this is the reason in life sometimes we are unable to find answers as we are asking the wrong questions. Simplify the way you manage your projects and teams. Switch to ProofHub. That’s why they say asking question is not important. It’s important to ask the right question. And just like everything else you can make it a habit to ask the right questions by practice. How can you do that? Here are some tips that might help - Understand the problem first  You cannot use a key to unlock the door as long as you know the right lock where it fits in. same is the case with solution. You can never reach to a solution unless you understand the problem first. To ask the right question, you must first ask yourself whether the problem is clear to you or not? That’s what they call as probing in tele-calling industry. The tele-callers are trained on how to ask the right questions i.e. how to probe. And, the first step in doing that is to rephrase the problem told by the caller. And, then begin with the probing. Probing narrows down all the possible wrong directions in which you might head before getting to the real problem. This can save you from not just hassle, but a lot of time wastage as well. Put yourself in other person’s shoes  I’m a big fan of the movie series Pirates of Caribbean. And an even bigger fan of Captain Jack Sparrow. Whenever someone asks me how am I able to handle problems at office so well I refer them to this quote by Jack Sparrow in the movie - ‘The problem is not the problem, it’s your attitude about the problem.’ Continue Reading Here…

This is a good question because there are quorans who ask stupid questions. For example I am now the most viewed on hypothetical battles which is a blessing and a curse. The blessing is I love to answer questions and I love to receive the bulk of them, the curse is that I get a lot of stupid questions. So for example. I’ll get asked “who will win in a fight between superman and squirrel girl”. This question is uber stupid because in no universe can squirrel girl win, there is nothing to debate here. They are so far apart in powers it’s like a man killing an ant. But if you ask me who would win between Namor and Ares that’s a great question because their feats and strengths are so similar that I am forced to look deeper to provide you a better answer, that said here’s how to ask a good question. Do some research before you ask, get a general understanding of the realm you are interested in.Think about your goal, what do you want answered within that question?Spell check and check for syntax etc. Sometimes I have to mind read what the quoran is trying to ask me.Make it short and sweet, if there are add on’s that you need to add like an image or something that you need explaining add it. So for instance you can say. “In this panel it looks like spider-man got blasted but isn’t hurt, how is that possible”. If I can’t see it I can’t answer it can I?Great question.

The recent change to Quora have seen a few change to the way questions works. I recently started writing answers and posting my own questions. First the length of a question has been increased. This is both good and bad as I see it. Good in that you can include comments within the question. Bad in that you end up with huge question, with multiple comments inside the question. First, word you question as simply as you can. Keeping enough detail that the author answering is not guessing what you are asking. Keep the number of question to a minimum. Write another question and reference other questions. Using comments and then putting a question mark at the end makes processing these questions annoying. A comments section has been added to each questions. This is an excellent place to add details. If the details are important to the context of a question try adding a See Comments to the question. Questions are the property of all Quoran. How well you write them will reflect well on how the question is treated and how good an answer you get. How a question get answered is up to the author. Vague questions get all sorts of answers. Last, if it is another question about how long is a normal penis and variation on this question, the answer has been written long ago. Beside, there is nothing you can do about it. Use the Quora’s search or Google to research the answer to your question. Exploration this way can lead to interesting treasures. Don’t be lazy. Asking a question that has already been asked won’t get you an answer if the authors don't see any merit in the question. Use the site with courtesy and respect. Remember, Be nice. Be respectful.

Having reviewed a lot of Quora questions, there are some words and phrases that I've found are frequently indicative of a poor question.  Perhaps the most frequent flaw in questions is asking a closed or poll question (which is contrary to policy, viz. Are poll and survey questions allowed on Quora?), rather than a more open question. Frequently offending words which suggest a closed question include: Is ... ? Does / Do ... ?Should ... ?Can ... ?Will ... ?All of the above questions can be answered with Yes or No, and thus are closed questions and less likely to provide insights than a more open question. Try to think whether you can replace such words with better interrogatives, such as: Why ... ?What ... ?How ... ?If you're having difficulty rephrasing to remove the offending interrogative, feel free to post your question to Need help wording a Quora question?, and I'm sure some other users will be happy to assist. Vague or unclear adjectives Questions should include some criteria that allow readers to judge whether an answer is useful, and another common error is using vague adjectives that can be entirely different depending on the perspective of the person who asked. bestgoodgreatfunAll of these words can have very different meanings to different people and in different contexts. Think about which property you're most interested in, instead: accuracymaterial qualityspeedaestheticscostdurabilityvaluereliabilityFor example, "What is the best computer for a student?" is somewhat meaningless, without knowing whether that student is studying programming, architecture, or liberal arts, what their budget is, whether they need a laptop that they can take to university every day, whether they need a particular OS, etc. Whereas "Which sub-$1,000 Windows laptop would you recommend for daily use of an architecture student in June 2013?" is far more likely to elicit relevant advice. Grammatically correct "How to ..." e.g. "How to ride a bike?" This form of question is reasonably common, partly perhaps because this might be how people ask questions of a search engine, but also because this is considered acceptable colloquial use in some countries (notably India). It doesn't, however, conform with conventional English rules of grammar and is best avoided.  A better way to phrase such a question is: "What is the fastest way to learn to ride a bike?"

Brevity, simplicity, clarity: Ask your question simply, clearly, and briefly so it’s easy to read through and more useful for the next researcher that asks a similar question. Edit your question before hitting the “Submit” button. Look for a way to shorten sentences, remove phrases or a even few words while preserving the question. Do this before hitting “Submit.” Most people are strapped for time and effort, so don’t test their resolve to help you. Minimize the barriers to coming to grips with the topic. Relevance, hot topic: People like answering a hot topic, partly because a lot of eyes will be on their answer. Something apropos and relevant to recent developments in the larger world/mediasphere will attract attention and recognition and reward the answerer for their efforts. Specificity: the question should be specific enough that the answerer can do a good job of answering without being forced to make sweeping generalizations about the situation. Many contribute answers because they want to add high-quality, relevant, reliable knowledge to the greater body of crappy, unreliable, biased information found elsewhere on the internet, a kind of pay-it-forward for a better world ideal. Comments and links provide background: use the question’s comments section (the speech balloon icon under the question headline to provide further background, internet links to comparable discussions. This will help to weed out the massive number of ways a question could be interpreted. Try to be brief, but there is also an opportunity here to flesh things out. Craft in some RELEVANT interest: Write the question and especially the background so it is as interesting and useful as possible. A brief RELEVANT story or description of your situation relating to the question may help. Letting some suspense or mystery into the details may make the question more compelling, but don’t let these details stray off topic too far or make it more difficult to answer. Add keywords: think about how someone else might research a similar question. Keep the question headline simple, but after hitting “submit” you can still add and remove relevant keywords above the Question headline (click the pencil icon). you can also work search terms into your comments, eg how would machine learning and 2018 manufacturing automation inform this question? Challenge and depth: Put a little careful thought into your question before hitting “Submit.” Would a person smarter than yourself be tempted to ask or answer this? Ask yourself if someone out there will find it fun or interesting to puzzle through this problem to a satisfactory conclusion. Some questions will make the answerer appear intelligent, so there is a reward for going to the effort. Specify what kind of answers would be most and least useful: speculate on the likely ulterior motives for answering. People (and other primates) have the desire or need to provide comfort, to encourage you to look optimistically at a problem, to entertain, inspire, correct an injustice, grab attention, establish intellectual authority, defend their political views, boast, cover their ass, take the piss, lie, or flog their software startup. A question providing different motives for responding might give your question more attention while obscuring the high-quality accurate answers. Use the comments section to indicate what kind of answer you’re looking for, and also which varieties you want to avoid. Evergreen: It can help to prime the question for evergreen answers, ie answers that are likely to remain useful over the long term, over the entire course of a person’s life. Some people will get more satisfaction from answering this kind of question instead of minutiae or the flavour of the month. Avoid leading questions: Don’t word your question to encourage a leading answer, or a biased reply. As stated above, many people here have a genuine desire to help people by providing accurate information and good advice. IMPORTANT: Request answers from people with a past history: after you hit “Submit,” the “Request” icon under the question headlines will allows you to search for answerers that might have been troubled by the same question. Ask yourself who would be strongly motivated to answer a given question because they have a history with it: they have struggled with the same issue or been plagued with a similar curiosity in the past. Wanting to share a solution to a problem you encountered is one of the most basic empathic motivations that people share.

Absolutely everybody writes good and bad questions. The trick is not to post the bad ones. Here’s how I do it: I write all questions in a document file.I review the entire file every morning.I move the best questions to the top of the file. I also edit them in any way I can: shortening them, catching typos and mistakes, making them clearer, etc.I avoid posting any question the day I write it (once in a while I make an exception). It’s better to sleep on new questions, and see them with a fresh eye in the morning.I move the weakest questions to the bottom of the file. They are probably too weak to ever ask, but they might give me ideas for better questions.When the file approaches five pages in length, I delete the last page. It’s all junk at that point.Each day, I post the best questions from the top of the file. I work my way down until I can detect a reduced quality, and stop.Evidence that this is good advice: If you are in the partner program, you are given 25 answer requests per question. If your questions don’t get answers, they are poor questions, and Quora lowers you allowance of answer requests per question. I’ve always been at 25, suggesting I am asking quality questions. Many other people report being at lower levels. Last weekend, I did an experiment. I thought maybe I was being too hard on myself regarding question quality, and decided to ask a series of questions outside my expertise (psychology). I asked questions about math, economics, programming, money, etc. I’m not ignorant of these topics, but I’m definitely no expert. They did poorly, and my answer request allowance dropped to 16. Obviously, I am not great at writing questions outside my areas of expertise, because most of them didn’t get any answers. Reviewing them now, I can see that many of them were weak or boring. Rule of thumb: I didn’t care much about the questions, which is a giveaway that others won’t either. Obviously, I want my request allowance to return to 25, so I am stepping back for a few days. I am giving my creativity a rest, so that I will come back with a series of strong questions that will be well-received. I am dumping all the questions in my document file that have been kicking around for more than a week—around 150–200 questions. When we ask bad questions, we are wasting our time. We are annoying people. We are lowering the quality of Quora. We won’t make more than a few pennies. A good question writer makes money. A person who spends a lot of time posting both good and bad questions is cutting their hourly earnings dramatically. One last note: Most of the questions on my profile are from the time before I learned to post only my best questions. Partners have the option of keeping their questions off their profile, which I do. I speak a few languages, and I want to have time to translate my questions before someone else does. I often like to consider whether a particular question will be well-received by other cultures, before flinging it at them. The Quora platforms in different languages have definite preferences for the kinds of questions they’ll answer. Also, I write mostly psychology questions. It’s particularly easy to write bad questions about psychology, if you don’t know much about it. I am bombarded with such questions. Thanks for the question. I hope that this information will reduce the amount of very weak questions that are being posted. Absolutely everybody writes good and bad questions. The trick is not to post the bad ones. Here’s how I do it: I write all questions in a document file.I review the entire file every morning.I move the best questions to the top of the file. I also edit them in any way I can: shortening them, catching typos and mistakes, making them clearer, etc.I avoid posting any question the day I write it (once in a while I make an exception).I move the weakest questions to the bottom of the file. It’s all junk at that point.Each day, I post the best questions from the top of the file. I work my way down until I can detect a reduced quality, and stop.

Search First, Then Ask Before you ask any question on Quora, you should first do a good search of what you are asking to see if others have asked it. Try the built in search first. But failing that, become a "power user" and try a Google search with the "site:" operator. For example, searching Quora for all Questions, Answers and Posts about Ghosts, enter the following in the Google Search box: site:Quora.com Ghosts If you find a question that asks what you want to know, but does not have adequate answers, you might choose to Re-Ask, by hitting the Re-Ask link. Do this instead of asking a new question. On the other hand, if no existing Question really gets it right, then add a new one. How? Click blue button to Ask Question (top right). Enter question and press Next. Correct grammar or punctuation as needed.See if the recommended questions address your concern, and click on them if so. Best to use Middle Mouse Button to open several in new tabs. If no other question does it for you, fill in: Write Question Details and click on blue button My Question is New. (Please add details!)Then add appropriate Topics. Had you searched, you may have found these: How do I add a new question to Quora? or How do I ask a question on Quora? or How can I ask questions more effectively?

I am guessing you are with the partner programme. Otherwise you would be rather asking “How do I write really good answers for Quora”. Apologies if I sounded rude. You do have quora's own data, it suggestes what topics need more question. You need to write questions that's usually on everyone's mind but they don't ask. One of my most popular question was why we can't send a satellite to a black hole to take pictures of it. This was way before the recent images came out. I was a bit surprised, my question came out of my interest in astrophysics, but there are several others who had the same thing on their mind. So it's all about asking questions that usually people would like to ask. What I have also realised is that, how popular someone is. The more popular you are on quora, the more interest people show towards whatever question you might have wrote.

You'll become amazingly good at asking questions when you figure out that this site is not intended to be the host of a question asking contest. Instead it is intended to be a place where people ask genuine questions - things you really want to know about. So if you sincerely have questions you’d like answered just do your best to word the questions concisely and yet offer as much information as you can - things that will aid people in knowing enough to offer a good answer. But if you regard this as a place to see how many questions you can post and how many answers they get you'll almost invariably end up looking like an idiot. It's pretty easy to detect people who do that. Instead of becoming popular people learn to automatically avoid clicking open the questions.

I come up with my best questions spontaneously. For example, if I'm having a disagreement with somebody and I want other people's opinions and feedback I come up with some good questions. Something as simple as, "What's the best way to clean woodwork?" That's a common question, and because so many people have so many different ways that work best for them, it's a good question that doesn't take a lot of time or thinking to answer. Or, I will read or hear something that triggers a question.My best questions are common but simple to answer, and interesting because people have vast differences in opinions, ways and reasons for the simplest things. There's more than one way to skin a cat :)) A good question is easy to answer when you ask the right people; at the right time, but we never know the best time. And unique since people have different perspectives on simple everything things. There's been many times I've had what I believe is a great question, but by the time I'm able to focus on how to ask it, the train has left the station. In short, my best questions are based on real life situations, may be not my life but still real. My questions would be better if I quickly make a note of it at the moment it comes to mind.

People who come here with the purpose of asking lots of questions are annoying and damage value of Quora. It reminds me of a high school student who seeks praise from their teacher for asking a good question. If that is what you are looking for, please confine your question asking to school. I suggest that you read Quora for a while and learn to appreciate the people who give good comprehensive answers to serious questions. Some of these amazing answers are written by people who are experts in the subject. People will devote a great deal to time to answer genuine or unique questions. Please do not insult potential answer writers by bombarding Quora with a variety of simple basic questions. Only a few people will bother to answer such questions and only with brief answers. Quora is not a contest to see who can ask the most questions.

How do I ask really great questions for Quora? Look at the world as you know it and ask: What if? Why? How? Where? When? Who? Find unique aspects, events, people, places, and things of the world no one else has yet asked about on Quora. Don’t limit yourself to what you can see or perceive in your immediate environment. Human knowledge extends beyond outer space and deeper than the molecule. Posting Your Question for Effect Part of the trick is in posting. Quora and Quora users have posted many tips on this. When you are posting your question, be sure to: compose and format it for best effect.[1]carefully choose the best topics.[2]request answers from the people best qualified and most likely to answer.[3]Another answer with great tips is User-10765974569827547511's answer to How do you personally select people to A2A (“Request Answer" feature) on Quora? Footnotes[1] What are the main policies and guidelines for questions on Quora?[2] What are the policies and guidelines for selecting topics for a Quora question?[3] Sarah Bowman's post in TIPS for Quorans

What are the strategies to ask good questions on Quora to get attention and engage people? This was immediately merged which means it was at least as good as an existing one that already started to receive answers. The site has attention and engagement covered by virtue of its popularity. It recently expanded into Spaces to capture the social network and blog crowds as internet use grows globally. The strategy is to get replies or comments. Requests to answer heighten chances. Then it is a matter of finding sources or letting the app rank them by default. For any topic, a review of associated content is going to reveal confusion or unknowns so those immediately invite critical inquiries. What is most relevant socially is up to interpretation at the time. That is similar to other forms of literature or media so there may be some overlap at the boundaries of each form. The question may also be posed to search engines and end up here anyway. Problem-solving often triggers information gathering which may look into data collection and then sift that into knowledge to present answers. Most users opt to ask again and cross their fingers that it will be seen by the right experts or that the bots have their preferences down. Curation is up to the user base who may be sharing reference posts to others. Questions are used to get to the next stage of development for the individual, group, or society from the Socratic method to testing machine intelligence. They prompt or prime deeper and wider viewpoints. All social, all good. See: Papers on Questioning

Base your question on scientific research. In my case, it’s in the field of Psychology. In the beginning, be ready to get reported for breaking the BNBR policy. All you need to do is repeal, explain that your question is based on studies using Base your question on scientific research. In my case, it’s in the field of Psychology. In the beginning, be ready to get reported for breaking the BNBR policy. All you need to do is repeal, explain that your question is based on studies using scientific research methods, and expect your question to be reinstated. Recently I’m encountering this phenomenon. My questions are getting merged with other questions having no relevancy. All I did was repeal and so far Quora moderation have unmerged my question. Oh yeah, here’s the most important factor. You gotta know what the heck you’re asking about. Needless to say, Quora provides the clearest and most reliable explanation. Quora Support's answer to On Quora, can you answer your own question? Is it bad form to answer your own question?

The most important thing is that the question be meaningful. If you ask, “is it possible to learn three languages while hanging upside down like a bat with a bag on your head?”, then the answer is going to be, “yes”. You might ask a survey question instead — have you attempted X, and what was the outcome? If you ask, “what is the best way to set fire to myself?” it’s not really possible to answer since we don’t know how you are measuring the goodness of the solutions. You might ask for, “the least expensive way to set fire to yourself given that you live in Manhattan?” as a more useful alternative. If you ask a question with a false premise such as — “given that the Earth is a obviously a pyramid created by drunk aliens, how we can consider global warming to be a man-made problem?” — then you can’t expect a meaningful answer either. You might better include the justification for your premise as a hypothetical part of the question — “I was off my head on acid the other day and it occurred to me that the Earth is a pyramid created by drunk aliens, and if that were the case how could we consider global warming to be a man-made problem?”

Ask for productivity / motivation / life meaning / life habits / life advice / success / … questions, because these seem to be the most successful on Quora (certainly they attract the most answers and views). Incidentally, they are also the most meaningless, since they just beg for the usual motivational and slogan-like answers (like “you can do it!”, “talk less, listen more”) which are very nice to hear but hardly actionable; also, no one really needs such advice to turn their life over: those who are moved by it don’t need it in the first place, and those who think they need it are very happy to hear it, and seek it continuously, but they don’t act on it. Also, extremely trivial science questions and question that are solved by googling them (like what is a <X>, where X has a good-sized Wikipedia article in almost any language, certainly in english) attract loads of answers (some comically wrong, the rest completely identical to each other), so you might want to give those ones a try, too.

Sean McKiernan has given some good examples of things to avoid. To paraphrase Albert Einstein, questions should be as simple as possible, but not simpler. Avoid adding details that will not really change the answer. “What should I study to become President of Mars?” does not need to be prefaced with one’s specific age or grade in school. Questions should not be leading, blaming, attacking, et cetera. When I am terribly bored, I edit questions of the form “Do you think X is Y?” to the form “Is X Y?” because all questions on Quora are implicitly asking us what we think. Phrases like “Do you think” or “Don’t you think” add words without adding meaning. If you are fortunate enough to have an operating system or browser that highlights words or phrases it thinks are incorrect, do take the time to look at what it has highlighted and make sure you’re saying what you mean to say.
